deliberation: Considered the rhetorical questions and the mention of Milcom dispossessing Gad. These are legal and historical images of inheritance and conquest; no explicit metaphor, simile, or personification beyond normal covenant/juridical language. Thus I treat the verse as basically literal.

Looked at 'sound the alarm of war', 'desolate mound', and 'its daughters'. The key figurative element is the use of 'daughters' for the dependent towns of Rabbah, personifying the city as a mother with daughters.

instances.english_text: And its daughters shall be set on fire
target: the smaller towns and villages belonging to Rabbah of the Ammonites
ground: derivative status, dependence, and shared fate with the central city
posture: portrays the whole urban network as a family subject to judgment
instances.explanation: The smaller towns are called the 'daughters' of Rabbah, personifying the main city as a mother whose daughters (satellite towns) share in her fiery destruction.

deliberation: Commands to 'howl, Heshbon' and 'cry out, daughters of Rabbah' address cities as if they were women mourning, giving a clear personification. Milcom going into exile can be literal for the idol; the dominant figure here is the personified cities.

instances.hebrew_text: הֵילִילִי חֶשְׁבּוֹן ... צְעַקְנָה בְּנוֹת רַבָּה חֲגֹרְנָה שַׂקִּים סְפֹדְנָה וְהִתְשׁוֹטַטְנָה בַּגְּדֵרוֹת
instances.english_text: Howl, O Heshbon, for Ai is ravaged! Cry out, O daughters of Rabbah! Gird on sackcloth, lament, And run to and fro in the sheepfolds.
target: the cities of Heshbon and Rabbah with their inhabitants
vehicle: women mourners crying, girding sackcloth, and running about the enclosures
ground: loud lament and frantic movement expressing great grief and fear
posture: summons the cities to respond to judgment as bereaved women, heightening the pathos of their fall
instances.explanation: Heshbon and the 'daughters of Rabbah' are addressed as women commanded to wail and lament, personifying the cities and their dependent towns as mourning females.

deliberation: Noted 'rebellious daughter' for Ammon and 'your valley is flowing'. Both are figurative: the nation is cast as a wayward daughter, and its fertile valley is depicted as 'flowing', a metaphor for abundant wealth/produce.

instances.english_text: O rebellious daughter
ground: ingratitude, defiance, and overconfidence typical of a wayward child toward a parent
posture: rebukes Ammon’s pride and faithlessness by casting her as a disobedient daughter toward God and proper order
instances.explanation: The nation is addressed as a 'rebellious daughter', conceptualizing Ammon as an unfaithful child in a family, highlighting her defiant attitude and misplaced trust.

instances.english_text: Your valley is flowing
vehicle: a valley that 'flows' (with liquid such as milk, water, or wealth)
ground: richness and productivity imagined as liquid overflow
posture: ironically highlights the object of Ammon’s pride—her fertile, prosperous land—just before announcing its vulnerability
instances.explanation: The valley is said to 'flow', using the imagery of flowing liquid to picture economic and agricultural abundance that undergirds Ammon’s arrogant boasting.

deliberation: Considered whether 'bringing terror' and people driven each before him were figurative. These phrases function as straightforward descriptions of panic and flight under attack, without a distinct metaphorical mapping beyond normal Hebrew usage.

The key phrase 'restore the fortunes' (hiphil of שוב + שבות) is a standard idiom for reversing a condition of calamity; it is more than strictly literal repatriation and functions figuratively for comprehensive restoration.

instances.english_text: I will restore the fortunes of the Ammonites
target: the overall condition and wellbeing of the Ammonites
vehicle: the turning back/bringing back of captivity
ground: a move from loss and humiliation to renewed wellbeing is pictured as captives being brought home
posture: softens the oracle with a promise that their judgment will eventually be reversed
instances.explanation: The idiom 'restore the fortunes' literally speaks of turning back captivity but functions figuratively for reversing the nation’s entire misfortune and restoring prosperity.

deliberation: The main non-literal element is 'their wisdom has gone stale / become rancid' (נִסְרְחָה), applying a verb of putrefaction to an abstract quality.

instances.english_text: Their wisdom has gone stale (has become rancid)
target: the wisdom and counsel of the sages of Teman/Edom
ground: what was once valued and useful has become offensive, unusable, and corrupt
posture: mocks the famed wisdom of Edom, declaring it spoiled and worthless in the face of God’s judgment
instances.explanation: Wisdom is described with a verb for rotting or stinking, likening Edom’s counsel to spoiled food that has lost its value and become disgusting.

deliberation: Identified (1) 'Esau' as a metonymy for the nation of Edom, and (2) 'go deep to dwell' as an idiomatic metaphor for withdrawing into remote hiding places for safety.

instances.english_text: For I am bringing Esau’s doom upon him
target: the nation of Edom as a political-ethnic entity
ground: the corporate identity of the people is bound up with their founding ancestor
posture: invokes the ancestral name to emphasize continuity in character and fate from Esau to Edom
instances.explanation: The doom of the contemporary nation is announced as 'Esau’s doom', using the ancestor’s name as a metonymy for the whole people descended from him.

instances.english_text: Sit down low / Go deep to dwell, O inhabitants of Dedan
target: inhabitants of Dedan seeking safety from the coming disaster
vehicle: going down into deep places to live (caves, remote recesses)
ground: safety is conceived as being deeply hidden or far removed from view
posture: urges them to seek the remotest hiding places as the only imaginable refuge from judgment
instances.explanation: The command to 'go deep to dwell' uses spatial depth metaphorically for retreating into extreme hiding places as protection from calamity.

deliberation: The verse uses hypothetical vintagers and thieves to set up a comparison with the coming plunder of Edom. These figures represent invaders, with the point that they typically leave something, unlike the thorough judgment implied.

instances.english_text: If vintagers were to come upon you... Even thieves in the night
target: the future plundering of Edom by invading forces
vehicle: grape harvesters stripping a vineyard, and night-time thieves plundering a house
ground: both remove valuable goods but usually leave some residue or take only what they need, unlike God’s judgment which will leave nothing
posture: sets up a vivid everyday comparison to prepare for the statement that divine judgment will exceed even these in totality
instances.explanation: Invading plunderers are envisioned as vintagers or thieves; these images frame the severity of the coming judgment by comparison with familiar but normally less total forms of loss.

deliberation: Key figurative elements: 'I have bared Esau' and 'I have uncovered his secret places' portray exposure of Edom’s hidden security as stripping a person naked and revealing hiding spots.

instances.hebrew_text: חָשַׂפְתִּי אֶת־עֵשָׂו גִּלֵּיתִי אֶת־מִסְתָּרָיו וְנֶחְבָּה לֹא יוּכָל
instances.english_text: I have bared Esau, I have exposed his place of concealment; he cannot hide
target: Edom’s hidden resources, refuges, and plans
vehicle: a man stripped bare and his secret hiding places uncovered
ground: complete exposure and vulnerability with no way to conceal oneself or one’s valuables
posture: asserts God’s power to penetrate and lay open every attempt at secrecy or escape
threatening display of omniscience and omnipotence
instances.explanation: God’s judgment on Edom is pictured as stripping Esau naked and exposing his hiding places, a metaphor for total exposure and vulnerability.

deliberation: Here God offers to care for 'orphans' and 'widows'. This casts God in human familial roles of guardian and protector; it is a relational metaphor for divine care after judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: עׇזְבָה יְתֹמֶיךָ אֲנִי אֲחַיֶּה וְאַלְמְנוֹתֶיךָ עָלַי תִּבְטָחוּ
instances.english_text: Leave your orphans with Me, I will rear them; let your widows rely on Me
target: the vulnerable survivors (orphans and widows) of the judged nation
vehicle: children entrusted to a guardian and widows trusting a protector
ground: God assumes the roles of provider and protector normally filled by human kin, ensuring life and security
posture: introduces an unexpected note of mercy, portraying God as a compassionate guardian amid judgment
instances.explanation: God’s promise to rear orphans and be trusted by widows metaphorically presents Him as their human-like guardian and protector.

deliberation: The dominant image is 'drinking the cup', a common biblical metaphor/idiom for undergoing divine judgment, not literally drinking liquid.

instances.hebrew_text: לִשְׁתּוֹת הַכּוֹס ... שָׁתוֹ יִשְׁתּוּ ... כִּי שָׁתֹה תִּשְׁתֶּה
instances.english_text: to drink the cup ... they have drunk ... you will surely drink
target: the experience of God’s judgment and punishment
vehicle: drinking a cup of potent drink, often to the dregs
ground: being forced to undergo a bitter, inescapable experience is likened to being compelled to drink a cup prepared by another
internalization and inevitability of the experience
posture: insists that Edom, like others, cannot escape fully undergoing the divinely allotted judgment
instances.explanation: The 'cup' stands for the portion of judgment assigned by God; to 'drink' it means to undergo that judgment in full.

deliberation: Most of the language about desolation is straightforward, but 'ruins forever' functions as prophetic hyperbole stressing an enduring, extreme devastation rather than a precise temporal statement.

instances.english_text: and all its towns shall be ruins for all time
target: Bozrah and the surrounding Edomite towns
ground: extreme and apparently irrevocable devastation is portrayed as if it will last without end
posture: employs prophetic hyperbole to underline the severity and long-lasting impact of the judgment
instances.explanation: The phrase 'ruins forever' overstates the duration in order to highlight the completeness and grievousness of Bozrah’s destruction.

deliberation: The verse reports hearing tidings from YHWH and an envoy being sent among the nations. These are standard prophetic and diplomatic descriptions rather than clear metaphors or similes.
Noted 'I will make you small among the nations'. 'Small' here is not physical stature but figuratively denotes insignificance and weakness.

instances.english_text: For I will make you least among nations
ground: being 'small' conveys lack of importance, power, and respect
posture: humiliates Edom by portraying its future as one of minimal significance among other nations
instances.explanation: Edom is not literally shrunken in size but is made 'small' in the sense of politically insignificant and despised.

deliberation: Two main figures: (1) Edom’s high fortresses/self-exaltation compared to an eagle’s lofty nest (explicit simile), and (2) God 'bringing you down' from there as a metaphor for humbling their proud status.

instances.english_text: Though you set your nest as high as the eagle
target: Edom’s fortresses and sense of security/self-exaltation
vehicle: an eagle’s nest made high on inaccessible cliffs
ground: great height and inaccessibility symbolize presumed safety and exalted position
posture: ironically undercuts Edom’s confidence in its 'high' security, showing it cannot escape divine reach
instances.explanation: Edom’s strongholds and pride are likened to an eagle’s high nest, suggesting an apparently impregnable position that God will nevertheless reach.

instances.english_text: From there I will pull you down
target: Edom’s elevated status and secure position
vehicle: someone physically brought down from a high place
ground: humiliation and loss of power are expressed as being dragged or brought down from height
posture: asserts God’s unilateral ability to humble the proud regardless of their perceived security
instances.explanation: To 'pull down' Edom from its high place is a metaphor for stripping it of its proud, secure status and subjecting it to humiliation.

deliberation: Identified Edom’s land as a personified patient with 'wounds' at which passers-by hiss in appalled reaction, representing the visible devastations of judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: כֹּל עֹבֵר עָלֶיהָ יִשֹּׁם וְיִשְׁרֹק עַל־כׇּל־מַכּוֹתֶיהָ
instances.english_text: Whoever passes by will be appalled and will hiss at all its wounds
target: the territory and cities of Edom after destruction
vehicle: a severely wounded person whose injuries onlookers see and hiss at in shock or scorn
ground: visible, shocking damage evokes horrified or derisive reactions from observers
posture: portrays Edom’s ruin as so severe that it becomes a spectacle eliciting horrified hissing from passers-by
instances.explanation: Edom is pictured as a person covered in wounds that others look at and hiss over, personifying the land’s ruins as bodily injuries.

deliberation: The verse explicitly compares Edom’s fate to the overthrow of Sodom and Gomorrah, a standard simile for total, divinely wrought devastation.

instances.english_text: It shall be like the overthrow of Sodom and Gomorrah and their neighbors
target: the coming destruction and depopulation of Edom
vehicle: the overthrow of Sodom and Gomorrah and nearby cities
ground: total, God-wrought destruction resulting in a place uninhabited by humans
posture: amplifies Edom’s future judgment by aligning it with the archetypal story of sodomite destruction
instances.explanation: Edom’s fate is likened to that of Sodom and Gomorrah, invoking the memory of complete devastation and enduring desolation.

deliberation: Saw (1) a simile comparing the invader/God’s action to a lion coming up from the Jordan thickets against a secure pasture, and (2) shepherd imagery for human rulers who cannot stand before God.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנֵּה כְּאַרְיֵה יַעֲלֶה מִגְּאוֹן הַיַּרְדֵּן אֶל־נְוֵה אֵיתָן כִּי אַרְגִּיעָה אֲרִיצֶנּוּ מֵעָלֶיהָ
instances.english_text: See, as when a lion comes up out of the jungle of the Jordan against a secure pasture: in a moment I can harry him out of it
target: the sudden irruption of God’s (or Babylon’s) invasion against Edom
military attack and displacement of current occupants
vehicle: a lion emerging from the thickets of the Jordan to attack a secure pasture and drive away what is there
predator assaulting a safe grazing place
ground: suddenness, ferocity, and irresistibility of the attack, dislodging those who felt secure
posture: graphically depicts the invasion as predatory and unstoppable, underscoring God’s sovereign initiative
instances.explanation: The coming attack on Edom is likened to a lion leaving the Jordan’s thickets to assault and drive off animals in a secure pasture, emphasizing surprise and overpowering force.

instances.english_text: And who is the shepherd that can stand up against Me?
target: any human ruler or protector of peoples
vehicle: a shepherd standing before a superior in defense of his flock
ground: the protective, guiding role of kings is pictured as shepherding a flock, yet even such a protector is powerless before God
leadership and care contrasted with divine supremacy
posture: affirms that no human leader can resist or counter God’s purposes for judgment
instances.explanation: Political leaders are called 'shepherds', a common royal metaphor, and none of them can stand before YHWH on behalf of their 'flocks'.

deliberation: The verse continues flock imagery: 'little ones of the flock shall drag them away' and 'he will make their pasture desolate over them'. This uses sheep and pasture as metaphors for the inhabitants and land of Edom/Teman.

instances.hebrew_text: אִם־לֹא יִסְחָבוּם צְעִירֵי הַצֹּאן אִם־לֹא יַשִּׁים עֲלֵיהֶם נְוֵהֶם
instances.english_text: Surely the shepherd boys / little ones of the flock shall drag them away; surely their pasture shall be aghast because of them
target: the people and land of Edom/Teman under judgment
vehicle: little sheep or young of the flock being dragged and a pasture laid over them
ground: Edom is likened to vulnerable sheep whose habitat (pasture) is overturned, emphasizing weakness and devastation of homeland
sheep-like helplessness and ruined grazing grounds
posture: depicts their defeat as humiliatingly easy and their land as thoroughly ravaged
instances.explanation: Edom and its land are portrayed through sheep-and-pasture imagery, presenting the people as vulnerable flock and their territory as a pasture laid waste.

deliberation: The earth 'shaking' at the sound of their fall, and the scream heard as far as the Sea of Reeds, form a vivid hyperbolic metaphor of cosmic impact and far-reaching wail.

instances.hebrew_text: מִקּוֹל נִפְלָם רָעֲשָׁה הָאָרֶץ צְעָקָה בְּיַם־סוּף נִשְׁמַע קוֹלָהּ
instances.english_text: At the sound of their downfall the earth shall shake; the sound of screaming shall be heard at the Sea of Reeds
target: the consequences and notoriety of Edom’s collapse
vehicle: an earthquake caused by their fall and a scream heard at a far-distant sea
ground: the event’s severity is conveyed as if it physically shakes the world and its cry carries an immense distance
magnitude and reach of the catastrophe
posture: employs cosmic and geographic hyperbole to stress how great and widely noted their downfall will be
instances.explanation: The earth is said to shake and the cry to be heard far away, exaggerating the physical effects to depict the overwhelming impact of Edom’s fall.

deliberation: Two clear figures: (1) the attacker rises and spreads wings over Bozrah 'like an eagle', and (2) the hearts of Edom’s warriors are compared to the heart of a woman in labor.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנֵּה כַנֶּשֶׁר יַעֲלֶה וְיִדְאֶה וְיִפְרֹשׂ כְּנָפָיו עַל־בׇּצְרָה
instances.english_text: See, like an eagle he flies up, he soars and spreads his wings against Bozrah
target: the invading force (probably Babylon) attacking Bozrah
vehicle: an eagle flying up, soaring, and spreading its wings over prey
bird of prey in attack posture
ground: speed, dominance from above, and the sense of inescapable threat from a powerful predator
posture: presents the invasion as predatory and high-flying, leaving Bozrah exposed beneath its wings
instances.explanation: The invader is likened to an eagle swooping down and overshadowing Bozrah with its wings, emphasizing swiftness and dominating reach.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָיָה לֵב גִּבּוֹרֵי אֱדוֹם בַּיּוֹם הַהוּא כְּלֵב אִשָּׁה מְצֵרָה
instances.english_text: And the heart of Edom’s warriors in that day shall be like the heart of a woman in travail
target: the inner courage and emotional state of Edom’s mighty warriors
vehicle: the heart of a woman in labor
ground: intense, overwhelming pain and fear that overpower normal strength
anguish, vulnerability, and loss of composure
posture: shames their reputed bravery by comparing it to the agonized and fearful feelings of a woman in childbirth
instances.explanation: Their warrior hearts are said to be like that of a woman in labor, a simile emphasizing terror and helplessness replacing courage.

deliberation: Found two related images: people 'melting' in anxiety, and anxiety described 'like the sea that cannot rest'. The key is the simile of unrest likened to a restless sea, with 'melting' as part of the same emotional picture.

instances.hebrew_text: נָמֹגוּ ... בַּיָּם דְּאָגָה הַשְׁקֵט לֹא יוּכָל
instances.english_text: They melt with anxiety, like the sea that cannot rest
target: the emotional state of Hamath and Arpad upon hearing bad news
vehicle: a sea in continual motion that cannot be quiet, and something melting away
ground: constant internal turmoil and loss of composure, akin to an agitated sea and something dissolving
posture: uses dynamic, physical images to communicate the intensity and persistence of their anxiety
instances.explanation: Their fear is described both as 'melting' and as like a sea that cannot be calm, a double image for inner disintegration and unceasing turmoil.

deliberation: Damascus is personified as a woman; 'trembling has seized her' and 'anguish and pains have taken hold of her like a woman in childbirth' give a childbirth simile and city-as-woman metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: רָפְתָה דַמֶּשֶׂק ... צָרָה וַחֲבָלִים אֲחָזַתָּה כַּיּוֹלֵדָה
instances.english_text: Damascus has grown weak... Trembling has seized her, pain and anguish have taken hold of her, like a woman in childbirth
target: the city of Damascus and its experience under threat
vehicle: a woman seized by labor pains, trembling and weakened
ground: sudden, gripping pain and fear, with loss of strength and desire to flee
posture: depicts Damascus as a terrified, laboring woman, intensifying the sense of vulnerability and dread
instances.explanation: The city is personified as a woman whose body is seized by labor pains, using childbirth imagery to describe the overwhelming distress of Damascus.

deliberation: The exclamation 'city of my praise, city of my joy' is evaluative language. It does not introduce a distinct metaphorical mapping beyond saying the city is the source/object of praise and joy; I treat it as essentially literal characterization.
The young men falling in the squares is literal battle imagery. The verb 'be stilled/silenced' (יִדַּמּוּ) for all the warriors is a common metaphor where death is described as silence.

instances.english_text: And all her warriors shall be stilled (silenced)
target: the fate of the warriors of Damascus
their death and cessation of activity
vehicle: being silenced, ceasing to make any sound
ground: the dead do not shout or speak; battle noise ends when fighters are killed
posture: conveys total defeat and death in a solemn, understated way by equating it with imposed silence
instances.explanation: The warriors are said to be 'silenced', a metaphor for their death and the abrupt end of battle clamor.

deliberation: The image of fire consuming walls and palaces is partly literal (siege and burning), but the verb 'eat/consume' for fire is a settled metaphor personifying fire as a devourer.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהִצַּתִּי אֵשׁ בְּחוֹמַת דַּמָּשֶׂק וְאָכְלָה אַרְמְנוֹת בֶּן־הֲדָד
instances.english_text: I will set fire to the wall of Damascus, and it shall consume the fortresses of Ben-hadad
target: the destruction of Damascus’s defensive walls and royal fortresses
ground: burning is likened to eating, emphasizing thorough, consuming destruction
consumption and removal of what is burned
posture: portrays the conflagration as an active devourer of elite structures, underscoring the end of Ben-hadad’s power
instances.explanation: Fire is said to 'consume' the fortresses, a personifying metaphor equating burning with devouring.

deliberation: This verse is mainly a historical superscription and direct command to attack Kedar and the kingdoms of Hazor. No clear metaphor, simile, or idiom beyond literal military language.
The looting of tents, flocks, equipment, and camels is literal. The catchphrase 'terror all around' (מָגוֹר מִסָּבִיב) is a Jeremianic idiom where fear is pictured as surrounding on every side.

instances.english_text: And shall proclaim against them: Terror all around!
target: the psychological state of the attacked nomads
vehicle: terror as something surrounding on every side
ground: the people feel hemmed in by danger and dread from every direction
posture: uses a fixed slogan to encapsulate the utter panic and sense of being surrounded by danger
instances.explanation: The idiom 'terror on every side' conceptualizes fear as encircling them, expressing pervasive, inescapable panic.

deliberation: Again, 'go deep to dwell' is an idiomatic metaphor for seeking remote, hidden refuge; the rest is literal description of Nebuchadnezzar’s plan.

instances.english_text: Go deep to dwell, O inhabitants of Hazor
target: inhabitants of Hazor trying to survive the coming attack
vehicle: sitting or dwelling deep down, in hidden or remote locations
ground: safety and concealment are imagined as being deep, far from the surface or usual routes
posture: heightens the urgency of the warning, suggesting that only extreme withdrawal offers hope of escape
instances.explanation: To 'go deep to dwell' uses depth as a metaphor for hiding in remote, protective places.

deliberation: Describes a 'tranquil nation' living securely without gates or bars and dwelling alone. These are plain descriptions of political and military vulnerability rather than overt figurative expressions.

Camels and flocks becoming spoil is literal. 'I will scatter to every wind those who have their hair clipped' uses scattering-to-winds imagery for dispersion, a familiar metaphor/hyperbole for total scattering.

instances.english_text: And I will scatter to every quarter those who have their hair clipped
target: the desert tribes characterized by clipped hair at their temples
vehicle: wind blowing things away in all directions
ground: total and wide-ranging dispersion is pictured as light objects carried off by winds from all sides
disintegration and loss of settled place
posture: emphasizes the thoroughness and helplessness of their exile by using an expansive, almost limitless scattering image
instances.explanation: The people are said to be scattered 'to every wind', a hyperbolic metaphor for being dispersed far and wide with no control.

deliberation: Hazor becoming a 'lair of jackals' and 'a desolation forever' is standard prophetic imagery for ruins inhabited by wild animals; 'forever' is hyperbolic for a very long-lasting desolation.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָיְתָה חָצוֹר לִמְעוֹן תַּנִּים שְׁמָמָה עַד־עוֹלָם
instances.english_text: Hazor shall become a lair of jackals, a desolation for all time
target: the ruined city and territory of Hazor
vehicle: a dwelling place for jackals, desolate forever
ground: abandonment by humans and occupation by scavengers signal deep, long-term ruin
emptiness, wildness, and duration of desolation
posture: paints a stark picture of complete and continuing devastation using animal-habitation imagery and temporal hyperbole
instances.explanation: Hazor is envisioned as a jackals’ lair and 'desolate forever', a hyperbolic metaphor for a ruined, uninhabited site taken over by wild animals.

deliberation: This is a narrative superscription marking when the word of YHWH came concerning Elam. It is straightforward prose with no figurative elements.
'I am going to break the bow of Elam, the mainstay of their strength' uses 'bow' as a metonymy for military power, and its breaking metaphorically denotes the shattering of that power.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנְנִי שֹׁבֵר אֶת־קֶשֶׁת עֵילָם רֵאשִׁית גְּבוּרָתָם
instances.english_text: I am going to break the bow of Elam, the mainstay of their strength
target: Elam’s military might and capacity to wage war
vehicle: their bow as the first/foremost of their strength, being broken
ground: a warrior disarmed by having his bow broken loses his ability to fight, symbolizing the loss of national strength
posture: announces decisive disempowerment of Elam’s martial resources via the symbol of their bow
instances.explanation: The 'bow' stands metonymically for Elam’s military power, and breaking it is a metaphor for destroying that power.

deliberation: The 'four winds from the four quarters of heaven' is a merism for all directions and functions as metaphorical language for forces of dispersion; scattering them 'to all those winds' extends this imagery.

instances.hebrew_text: אַרְבַּע רוּחוֹת מֵאַרְבַּע קְצוֹת הַשָּׁמַיִם ... וְזֵרִתִים לְכֹל הָרוּחוֹת הָאֵלֶּה
instances.english_text: I shall bring four winds against Elam from the four quarters of heaven, and scatter them to all those winds
target: the dispersion of Elam’s people and the forces that carry them away
vehicle: four winds from four corners of heaven driving things in all directions
ground: invasion and forced migration come from every direction, resulting in a diaspora spread to all points
posture: presents Elam’s scattering as cosmically wide and divinely orchestrated using meristic wind imagery
instances.explanation: The reference to four winds from the four corners of heaven uses a merism for all directions, depicting Elam’s people as scattered everywhere by these winds.

deliberation: Identified two figures: (1) 'the heat of My anger' (חרון אפי), a common metaphor for intense wrath as burning heat, and (2) 'I will send the sword after them', using 'sword' as a metonymy for ongoing warfare pursuing them.

instances.english_text: I will bring disaster upon them, My flaming wrath
target: the intensity of God’s anger against Elam
vehicle: burning or flaring of the nose/anger, i.e., heat
ground: strong emotion is likened to burning heat that flares up, conveying vehemence
posture: emphasizes the fervor and seriousness of the judgment by describing God’s anger as burning
instances.explanation: God’s anger is pictured as 'flaring' or 'burning', a metaphor equating emotional intensity with physical heat.

instances.english_text: And I will dispatch the sword after them
target: ongoing military pursuit and violence against Elam
vehicle: a sword being sent after people as if it were an active pursuer
ground: the instrument of killing stands for the armies and battles that chase and attack them
posture: communicates relentless military pressure until Elam is consumed, by personifying the sword as a pursuing agent
instances.explanation: The 'sword' metonymically represents warfare; God 'sending the sword' after them means he will cause continuous armed assaults.

deliberation: The verse says, 'I will set My throne in Elam', which is metaphorical language for establishing God’s direct sovereignty there, with 'throne' functioning as a symbol/metonymy of rule.

instances.english_text: And I will set My throne in Elam
target: God’s sovereign rule and presence over Elam
vehicle: placing a royal throne in a territory
ground: a throne signifies the seat and exercise of authority; putting it in Elam indicates that God’s rule will be established there
posture: declares the replacement of local kings with God’s direct kingship over Elam
instances.explanation: God does not literally move a physical throne, but uses 'throne' as a symbol of His rule, promising to establish His sovereign authority in Elam.

deliberation: Reuses the idiom 'restore the fortunes' (’ashiv et-shevut) for Elam in the latter days, again a figurative expression for reversing national misfortune.

instances.english_text: I will restore the fortunes of Elam
target: Elam’s future status, wellbeing, and prosperity
ground: moving from calamity to blessing is framed as previously taken people being brought back home
posture: concludes the oracle with eschatological hope, using a familiar idiom of reversal
instances.explanation: As in other prophetic texts, 'restore the fortunes' uses captivity language figuratively to describe God’s reversal of Elam’s national misfortune.
